title: The Chinese Helvetica
content:
I am looking for a Chinese character set that has similar qualities to a modern san serif like Univers, Frutiger or Helvetica. (meaning not script)  
If anyone has a suggestion or could even direct me to a Chinese foundry or type designer, I would be eternally grateful.
author: Jem

comments.content:
"Are you using OS X?"

Yes indeed.

**_[According to Linotype:](http://web.archive.org/web/20150217121307/http:/www.linotype.com/13446/helveticaroman-font.html)_**

Many customers ask us what good non-Latin typefaces can be mixed with Helvetica. Fortunately, Helvetica already has Greek and Cyrillic versions, and [Helvetica™ World](http://web.archive.org/) includes a specially-designed Hebrew Helvetica in its OpenType character set. But Linotype also offers a number of CJK fonts that can be matched with Helvetica.

**Chinese fonts that pair well with Helvetica:**  
 [DF Hei](http://web.archive.org/web/20150217121307/http:/www.linotype.com/110191/dfhei-family.html) _(Simplified Chinese)_  
 [DF Hei](http://web.archive.org/web/20150217121307/http:/www.linotype.com/110207/dfhei-family.html) _(Traditional Chinese)_  
 [DF Li Hei](http://web.archive.org/web/20150217121307/http:/www.linotype.com/110368/dflihei-family.html) _(Traditional Chinese)_  
 [DFP Hei](http://web.archive.org/web/20150217121307/http:/www.linotype.com/110533/dfphei-family.html) _(Simplified Chinese)_

**Japanese fonts that pair well with Helvetica:**  
 [DF Gothic](http://web.archive.org/web/20150217121307/http:/www.linotype.com/110162/dfgothic-family.html?DSESSID=&PHPSESSID=a04b0657aaf1e74cf0314ee8b3f82f6c)  
 [DF Gothic P](http://web.archive.org/web/20150217121307/http:/www.linotype.com/110152/dfgothicp-family.html?DSESSID=&PHPSESSID=a04b0657aaf1e74cf0314ee8b3f82f6c)  
 [DFHS Gothic](http://web.archive.org/web/20150217121307/http:/www.linotype.com/110223/dfhsgothic-family.html?DSESSID=&PHPSESSID=a04b0657aaf1e74cf0314ee8b3f82f6c)

**Korean fonts that pair well with Helvetica:**  
 [DFK Gothic](http://web.archive.org/web/20150217121307/http:/www.linotype.com/110320/dfkgothic-family.html?DSESSID=&PHPSESSID=a04b0657aaf1e74cf0314ee8b3f82f6c)

Many thanks.

URW++ have Chinese fonts, cheaper licensing than others. We have spec’d them for Bosch and other international clients. [www.urw.de](http://web.archive.org/web/20150217121307/http:/www.urw.de/ "www.urw.de")

I realize I'm coming into this very late, but for future reference, buying the fonts directly from Dynacomware is _much_ cheaper than from Linotype, at $25 a pop. They're one of the cheapest type foundries for East Asian stuff (if not _the_ cheapest), and they offer packs of fonts at a further huge discount as well.

[http://www.dynalab.com/Products/Wheretobuy/DynaComwareGlobal/tabid/645/l...](http://web.archive.org/web/20150217121307/http:/www.dynalab.com/Products/Wheretobuy/DynaComwareGlobal/tabid/645/language/en-US/Default.aspx "http://www.dynalab.com/Products/Wheretobuy/DynaComwareGlobal/tabid/645/language/en-US/Default.aspx")

Note that for Japanese, Morisawa's Medium Gothic BBB was actually packaged with Helvetica for a long time. They have since replaced it with a proprietary face in the OpenType version of the font (Helvetica was seen as having glyphs that were a wee bit too small and heavy), but it's still very close to Helvetica aside from the _a_ (has a cut-off tail like in Arial or the heavier weights of Helvetica, but otherwise it resembles Helvetica's _a_ more than Arial's), the _g_ (double-story), the _r_ (the top is a little shorter), and the _y_ (the tail curves a little differently).

Here's a comparison of the two versions:  
 [http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/06/Gothic\_BBB\_sample.png](http://web.archive.org/web/20150217121307/http:/upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/06/Gothic_BBB_sample.png "http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/06/Gothic\_BBB\_sample.png")

Adobe Acrobat now includes a sans serif Simplified Chinese font (AdobeHeitiStd-Regular) that can be used for authoring purposes, and we also bundle this font with many of our other applications (when it is localized for China). It's a very good design, and covers GB 18030, meaning that all of the hanzi in the URO and Extension A are included, to the tune of 30K glyphs. We purchased this design from Changzhou SinoType.

Dr. Ken Lunde  
Senior Computer Scientist, CJKV Type Development
